I'm reminded of my own article published in the English monthly, "Gyan Vitaranam" of Nov, 2014. Here it goes: FATE OR FREE-WILL, THAT’S THE QUESTION, Life is like a game of cards. The hand you are dealt is destiny; the way you play it is free-will. Your personality, physical and mental, you are born with, and the environment, your familial, cultural and financial, you are born into, make up your fate. This is your initial deposit in the account of your life. A person is defined by the choices he makes on a day-to-day basis and by the actions he takes in response to the stimuli of the world around him. Essentially, an individual is determined by the degree to which he exercises his own free-will. There is a stillness and permanence about the past; it changes not and has solidity, like a statue cast in bronze or marble. The present is the product of the past. The past has determined the present. And the future is the product-to-be of the present. The great philosopher-poet Sri Aurobindo has a beautiful phrase for the present moment: "the pure and virgin moment---that razor’s edge of time and existence which divides the past from future". The present is yet unlived and unspoilt, and therefore, is very much changeable. Where there is a will, there is a way. Here your free-will comes in. You can change the present the way you want, and consequently, the future too, for the future, as said earlier, is the outcome of the present. Positive thinking has an effective role to play. It has been proved that most of us have been living far below our potential. We have to analyze and assess our merits and demerits, without bias and with a clinical precision. Then we have to start developing and making optimal utility of our merits. If we move ahead with a passion and determination, none can stop us except our own negativity and habitual lethargy. Lots of folks mistake their bad management of life for destiny. But positive thinking has its own limits which our motivational speakers don’t concede, at least in public. Now-a-days, their stereotypes are ubiquitous and they keep dishing out, day in and day out, their worn-out fables, parables and platitudes. Imagine a hen tied to a post with a metre-length rope. The hen is no doubt is bound and its freedom of movement is apparently curtailed. All the same, it can move as freely as it wants within the circle described by the radius of a metre. If it rues that it is fettered and becomes disheartened that it cannot move, it forgoes its freedom of movement even within that circle. Positive thinking and motivation help it to make maximum utility of the available freedom of movement. But no amount of inspirational talk can make it get beyond the circle. We can create our own destiny and enjoy living to the limits of our potential. Each of us is unique. It has been found that the average person only employs a small per cent-age of his latent abilities. He has various physical and mental resources which he habitually fails to use. You and I have such resources. Evaluate your strengths and weaknesses. Then, start building on your strengths and discover how many talents and abilities you have that you didn’t even imagine you had. If once we begin putting them to optimal use, we will be changing our otherwise statuesque fate and fulfilling our possible destiny with an informed free-will, and that too, with a vengeance! This is the miracle of life, this celebration—living and enjoying the good life to the limits of one’s IQ and EQ!

In human life, existence precedes essence. That is, in human consciousness, the conceptual entertainment of unrealized possibility becomes a major factor. This needs unpacking. What we are as human beings is not decided for us by God, by history, by society, by class, or by our personal past. We decide in the act of existing. We may try to flee the radical freedom and responsibility that this places upon us, but such evasion is itself an act of decision and free-will as to what we are. Moreover, there are no pre-established rules that either normatively or factually govern our existence. Each situation is unique. If we choose to apply a rule, that is the choice for which we are responsible. There is no predetermined or preordained end toward which we are directed (rigid teleology). The future is radically open, it is a line in becoming. In other words, it is the note of the Novum, the qualitatively new, which is of the essence of the future to which one is open, and the future has this openness not merely because human decisions are not predetermined, but rather because the radically new, the creative novelty, cannot be anticipated. Furthermore, the human condition is radically contingent and ambiguous. There is no preexistent plan that includes us and assign us a specific role in the scheme of things. We experience ourselves as “thrown” into the world. It is in this situation, marked by contingency and an open future, that we must assume our existential freedom and responsibility for ourselves, for our societies, and for our world with its non-human communities of life. Our actual conscious as well as pre-reflective experience includes making decisions among various possibilities of thought and action. That is to say, we adopt some real possibilities and abandon others. In the present we are causal agents rather than merely the products within the parameters of the past. These experiences are supported by both common sense and phenomenological evidence. If we take seriously these experiences and ideas, we can assert that there is a difference between what may happen and what does happen. That is, there are more possibilities than actualities. Some possibilities for the future are actualised, while some are not. If we accept this thesis, then we can understand our experience moment by moment as the product of the interactions between the actualities of the past and the relevant potentialities in the present. The options we are confronted with offer themselves as pure potentials, not necessities. It is the reality of multiple possibilities that requires freedom and decision making but does not determine what that decision is or will be. Our destiny is freedom.

What is destiny? It is not every event in a life, and it is not the final outcome of it. What it does is provide a rough draft based on the lessons our spirit has chosen. As our lives are not micromanaged, it is possible that some destined events will not transpire, and they may subsequently be replaced with a new destiny. Only some elements of destiny are set before a spirit takes a lifetime. Others are set as that life unfolds and the choices we make determine our life path. For most of us in today’s world, life holds so many options that it cannot be known, prior to it, what our needs will be. Destiny does not refer to every event in our life. It always includes the lessons chosen by our spirit and usually will include some of our relationships, i.e., parents, children, or spouse. Other possibilities are a major or chronic illness, education and career choices, and any number of life challenges. Do we make our own destiny or is it written out for us? To the extent that our destiny is based on the lessons chosen by our spirit, it is our spirit who designs it, but, as noted above, that is a rough draft. In addition, the Creator adds some aspects of destiny and these will be known by our guardian. So, to some extent our destiny is written, but it is not written in ink, much less in concrete. Our spirit and guardian will attempt to influence and guide us to elements of our destiny (and the mundane events of our daily lives) but they cannot assume control of our lives. It is up to us to be alert to their efforts. We can do that by following a spiritual path that draws us closer to our spirit, including the practice of prayer, meditation, and reflection. To answer your question, I draw a distinction between Destiny and Fate. The former (destiny) is decided prior to your birth/incarnation (e.g. you agree to your culture, birth gender, parents, country of birth, DOB, abilities [e.g. musical, intellectual, psychic, manual, art etc], choice of body, career, crossroad meetings, life-changing events etc). Our spirit / soul / Higher-self guides us on this. The latter (fate) are the choices and decisions we make while incarnate as human beings, with our human mind, emotions, ego, personality etc. Some events are seen as fateful i.e. unavoidable (really the word is destiny-ful?) and in reality, that can be the case e.g. life changing events i.e. we chose it before we were born, from a spiritual perspective (even though our humanness / ego really doesn’t like it and argues to the contrary). I am going to add that, from the soul/spirit/Higher-self perspective, there is no judgement on whether we follow any of our destiny. We have free will. And for most of us, we distract and make decisions and choices from very human perspectives, which is part of being human ~ the human experience. Knowing your destiny is not always comfortable either because if we did know, we might consciously go out of our way to avoid the very thing we agreed to, from a spiritual perspective, prior to birth.

Joshua Rothman in a review of Anna Karenna sums up Tolstoys’ perspective on fate this way: “He believes that we make choices, and that our sense of free will is based on something real. But he also has a deep respect for the complexity and power of our circumstances, and he considers our personalities and psychologies to be “circumstances,” too. There are limits to what we can do out there in the world, and there are also limits to what we can feel, endure, know, and imagine within ourselves.” Is “Anna Karenina” a Love Story? How sure are you that you are in complete control of your own emotional reactions to particular circumstances that you can always guarantee you are a maker of your own fate?

Even something so small as a human being is made up of a staggering number of atoms, each of which rigidly follows a set of deterministic rules whose aggregate result determines the fate of the organism, and each of which is composed of fundamental particles which may or may not be themselves following deterministic rules. It has been said that the universe is already the most compact computer capable of determining its own fate. This makes sense: atoms are much smaller than any computing circuitry capable of modeling their behavior. Science takes constant advantage of the vast computing power of the universe by whenever possible conducting experiments rather than modeling results. It’s generally easier, and always more accurate. Under these conditions, we could prove the universe was deterministic if we could predict its future accurately using a deterministic model. But none of our models are, or ever could be accurate enough to perfectly predict the future of something as complicated as a human being in society. By comparison, predicting the weather is trivial. So the preliminary answer to your question is that we don’t know, and furthermore do not have, nor will ever have the computing horsepower to ascertain whether human behavior is fundamentally deterministic. But that means that to us it is not - we can never predict with any accuracy exactly what we will do, or what will happen to us, even in the very short-term future. So that’s your answer: as far as we’re concerned, our futures are unpredictable and therefore not fated; whether fundamentally that is true or not. So, feel free to make your own fate.

Yes, according to the Vedas, destiny does exist. Whatever happens in this life is determined by previous lives, and whatever happiness and distress you are due in this life is fixed at birth. In proportion to the extent of one's religious or irreligious actions in this life, one must enjoy or suffer the corresponding reactions of his karma in the next. O best of the demigods, we can see three different varieties of life, which are due to the contamination of the three modes of nature. The living entities are thus known as peaceful, restless and foolish; as happy, unhappy or in-between; or as religious, irreligious and semireligious. We can deduce that in the next life these three kinds of material nature will similarly act. SB 6.1.45- 46 It is clear from the above verses from Srimad Bhagavatam that one life is the spring board to the next, while simultaneously delivering the results of our past life. How you react in this life to the results of your past life determines the next life. So to break that down, what it means is that this life is set, but your next life is not. So destiny acts within this life, and your activities in this life determine your destiny in the next life. So we create our own destiny and then get the opportunity to create another and then another. So while destiny exists, it is not some outside force that acts on us, it is the result of activities. Once our destiny is locked down at the end of our life, then when we take birth again, it can be changed, but not by us. We cannot meddle with the laws of material nature. If we could then no one would ever feel distressed or even stressed, never get diseases, grow old or die. This is not happening now, and never has. These experiences are forced on us and we cannot avoid them. What we can do is surrender to the master of material nature Lord Krishna and engage in His service and if necessary He can change our destiny. It’s not something that we can ever check because we only live one life one time, and can never know what would have happened if we had made different choices. But on the upside we can become indifferent and detached to the experiences that our destiny deliver to us, but rising above the three modes of nature which are the delivery system for our material happiness and distress. The Vedas deal mainly with the subject of the three modes of material nature. O Arjuna, become transcendental to these three modes. Be free from all dualities and from all anxieties for gain and safety, and be established in the self. Bg 2.45 Material happiness and distress, which let’s face it is what really concerns us about destiny, can be bypassed altogether while not being changed. Happiness and distress are one of the dualities of the material world, but they only affect us if we identify as a material body. If we identify and realize our spiritual nature, then the workings of material nature won’t affect us. This is the goal of self-realization, to understand the self as spirit soul, eternal servant of Krishna and so become indifferent to the attempts of destiny to deliver happiness and distress to us.

This world of humanity is based on full freedom and absence of any forcible destiny. After burning the finger, you may say that you have put the finger in the fire due to the destiny. God has destined the specific system, which links every action with a specific fruit. After putting your finger, God is not ordering the fire to burn it. The subsequent fruit for a specific work is already destined. God or the destiny does not interfere with the choice of your selection of a specific work. Even the so called past destiny does not interfere with your works. The composition of your psychology is fixed based on your past deeds. Thus, work is responsible for the will and the will is the generator of the work. You do something based on your Samskara. The planet gives its correspondent fruit immediately. You blame the planet for guiding you to do a specific work and this is totally wrong. A planet is only destined to give the specific result linked with your specific action. The specific work is based on your specific psychological pattern only. The horoscope gives the composition of your specific psychological pattern. Since your future actions also depend on the same pattern, future prediction can be easily given. This is related to the question of free will … but it is not a yes/no thing. Better is to ask about the extent to which we are in control of what happens to us. To what extent do our decisions matter? If I step off a cliff, I cannot just decide to float away without much better prep. I am destined to arrive at the bottom of the cliff. However, what most people are thinking of with destiny is a mysterious supernatural force that controls the events of our lives in the sense of “Appointment in Samarra” and a great deal of time-travel stories. There is no reason to suspect a supernatural force. The instances where we have no control of where we end up, we call those: natural laws. The picture from classical mechanics (which includes relativity) is purely deterministic. However, the emerging picture of a statistical universe, one that is inherently uncertain, leaves room for the possibility to make decisions — to choose from a range of possible futures. So far there is not enough evidence to call it for determinism/fate/destiny. Right now, our best evidence suggests that, by understanding the natural laws that bind us, we can shape our path to the future. We can have that kind of power with Nature instead of over Her. If hard determinism is true, then it makes no difference: since I have no choice but to act as though I have some control over my destiny.
